newsitem.title: USA: Summit Medical revises 96 loss downward.
newsitem.headline: Summit Medical revises 96 loss downward.

text.p: Summit Medical Systems Inc, which said last month it expected to revise downward results for three years, on Friday reported a revised net loss for 1996 of $12,836,000, compared with the previously reported loss for the year of $10,368,000.

Revenues for the year were revised downward to $17,172,000, compared with $19,543,000 previously. The 1996 net loss includes a $4,746,000 charge associated with the buyout of Cordillera LLC, a joint venture with Duke University, and expenses related to the acquisition of C.L. McIntosh & Associates.

For 1995, Summit Medical, restated downward its net loss to $9,024,000 from a loss of $7,163,000 previously, and revised revenues to $15.5 million from $17.7 million previously. For 1994, the net loss was restated to $1,173,000 from a previously reported net loss of $300,000, and revenues were revised to $11.3 million from $12.3 million.

Cumulative revenues for the three-year-period were $5,638,000 less than originally reported, a 11 percent reduction. Amounts for 1995 and 1994 included the results of acquisitions that were accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis, Summit said.

Summit, which provides management systems and information services for the healthcare industry, said it retained the law firm of Dorsey & Whitney LLP to represent the company in three class-action shareholder law suit.
The law firm also will represent it in an investigation by the Security and Exchange Commission, which Summit said it is cooperating with fully.
"With respect to 1996 operating results and performance, we simply did not meet our expectations," Kevin Green, president and chief executive, said in a statement.
